clinical_study.brief_title: Women's Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) Research Study
clinical_study.official_title: The Psychophysiology and Neurobiology of PTSD Across the Menstrual Cycle

collaborator.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine the relationship between trauma and startle. The investigators are also looking at the effect of menstrual phase on this relationship.

detailed_description.textblock: The investigators are trying to understand if there is a relationship between the experience of traumatic events such as those experienced by people with post traumatic stress disorder and reactivity to startling noises or mild threats. So, the investigators are looking at startle reflex, heart rate, and stress hormone responses to short noises and small shocks in people exposed to trauma and who either do or do not have PTSD. Additionally, the investigators will be looking at how the menstrual cycle impacts these processes. The investigators know that women have twice the risk for developing PTSD and some research suggests that stress hormones change during the menstrual cycle and may have an effect on risk.

biospec_descr.textblock: Urine, blood and saliva samples are taken. Only blood and saliva samples are retained and used to measure stress hormone levels.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women, ages 18-55 years old who have a regular menstrual cycle and who can come in to participate in the afternoon
Exclusion Criteria:
- Long-term medications, oral or steroid contraceptives, irregular menstrual cycle
